stream_context.summary: Kaze continues building Course 11 (provisionally titled “Oily Boily Bay”), focusing on new platforming mechanics: a timed wind-turbine actor (vertical and horizontal variants) and hookable cranes for red-coin traversal. The stream also includes performance/engine talk (ROM size, FPS gains, real N64 footage with extreme draw distance), plus broader creator-life topics: YouTube vs Twitch, video strategy, and a recent tennis-elbow diagnosis.
stream_context.significance_reason: Introduces and debugs a new core traversal mechanic (timed turbines) and expands traversal tooling (hookable cranes), while also surfacing meaningful creator/business context (Twitch→YouTube transition, algorithm frustration) and engine/performance milestones (ROM size tracking, real N64 showcase).

findings.summary: Course 11 is the current focus (11 of 15 total courses), with major areas largely modeled and attention shifting toward platforming mechanics and mission structure.
Kaze confirms the project is being kept within the N64’s 64MB ROM ceiling; during the stream the build sits around ~42.8MB while editing content as he goes.

He defines the three mission slots/ideas for the course (including a boss-focused mission and a separate “eaten by a block” sub-area concept), and frames the power-generator zone as a key setpiece for traversal and red coins.

Kaze prototypes a wind-turbine platforming mechanic and decides it should likely operate on an on/off timing cycle to create deliberate timing jumps (e.g., long jump into a turbine at the right moment to get launched farther).

He implements the turbine behavior by referencing/adapting existing windmill/propeller code, adds parameters for timing and direction, adjusts collision so players don’t fall into the turbine, and iterates on acceleration, max speed, and particle direction/feedback.

A major blocker appears when trying to rotate turbines to different orientations: Euler-angle/gimbal-lock behavior prevents achieving the desired axis rotation. Kaze resolves it by rotating the model 90° in the 3D asset itself and creating a separate oriented model variant so the in-engine rotation behaves correctly.

Red-coin platforming is planned to be “baby easy,” emphasizing readability and avoiding awkward requirements like back-jumps; he places early red coins around turbines to make the intended movement obvious.
findings.quote: Basically anything should be possible without a back jump.

findings.summary: Kaze argues against excessive cosmetic toggles (old/new UI elements, fonts, meters), saying that beyond accessibility and meaningful gameplay settings, too many options dilute design intent and add unproductive work.
findings.quote: At that point, just make your own game.

findings.summary: He adds/extends crane traversal by making hooks that can attach to crane actors via a simple hierarchical setup (placing actors near each other to auto-attach), then tunes positioning/rotation to enable skillful “pro gamer” movement on cranes.

Engine/performance context: Kaze cites major FPS gains since earlier engine rewrites (e.g., the “zoo” area improving from ~9 FPS on the original engine to ~40–50 now) and shows real N64 footage of Course 1 with extreme/infinite draw distance; he notes interpolation artifacts below 30 FPS that may need fixing and acknowledges current instability/crashes despite fast performance.
findings.quote: I literally don’t even think it’s crazy to say anymore that this looks like a GameCube game.

findings.summary: He’s actively transitioning streaming from Twitch to YouTube, celebrates a ~50-viewer record on YouTube, and frames Twitch as “going down the gutter,” making YouTube growth strategically important.

Kaze vents that an April Fools “touching grass” meme video outperformed several high-effort technical and level-preview videos, reinforcing his belief that YouTube currently rewards background-noise content and pushes creators toward more shitposting.
findings.quote: This stupid fucking meme video, 160k… No one gives a shit about anything.

findings.summary: Personal update: his bike was stolen (putting him in a bad mood), and he missed a stream due to a long doctor visit where he was diagnosed with tennis elbow; he rejects suggested painkillers and a cortisol injection, preferring to self-treat and expressing frustration with the healthcare system.

He briefly identifies one of the hardest past bugs he’s faced: a DMA copy issue tied to a stack variable causing 16-byte alignment problems that only manifested on real N64 hardware (not emulators), making it difficult to diagnose.
Lilaa previously complained about the stream camera framing; Kaze adjusted it and solicited feedback on whether it works better now.
Lilaa provides a new stream banner asset during the stream; Kaze adopts it immediately and praises it, noting how hard it is to find good YouTube banner references.
A contributor suggestion (in chat) proposes tying turbine particle spawn speed to the turbine’s angular speed and smoothing acceleration; Kaze agrees and implements the idea during debugging.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: This stupid fucking meme video, 160k… No one gives a shit about anything.
memorable_quotes.context: He compares view counts between high-effort programming/level work and a viral April Fools meme, revealing frustration with what the platform rewards.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: At that point, just make your own game.
memorable_quotes.context: His pushback against viewers asking for endless cosmetic toggles (old HUD, meters, fonts), emphasizing authorial intent and scope control.

key_stories.title: Building the timed wind-turbine mechanic (and losing a fight to gimbal lock)
key_stories.summary: Kaze designs a new turbine traversal tool intended to create timing-based jumps and satisfying movement in Course 11’s industrial/oil setting. The effort becomes a case study in how small-feeling mechanical features can explode into deep technical and asset-pipeline problems on a retro engine.
key_stories.challenge: Create vertical/horizontal turbines that push Mario reliably, look readable, and support red-coin platforming—while fighting engine rotation limitations (Euler/gimbal lock).
key_stories.process: He adapts existing windmill/propeller code, adds timing (on/off cycles) and direction parameters, tunes acceleration/max speed, fixes collision so Mario can’t fall into the turbine, and improves particle feedback. When rotations refuse to behave (yaw/roll/pitch not affecting the expected axis), he diagnoses gimbal lock and ultimately rotates the turbine model in the 3D asset to produce a separate oriented variant.
key_stories.outcome: A working turbine actor exists with timing-based behavior and usable vertical/horizontal variants, enabling planned red-coin routes; however, the solution requires asset duplication/orientation work and highlights engine constraints.
key_stories.key_quote: MFs will never believe you how fucking hard it was to make this thing spin this way around.

key_stories.title: A meme beats the work: YouTube incentives vs serious dev videos
key_stories.summary: Kaze openly wrestles with the mismatch between what he values (technical breakthroughs, level work) and what the algorithm rewards (jokes and background-noise content). This becomes both a business decision point and a creative identity tension he’s actively navigating.
key_stories.challenge: High-effort engineering and level-preview videos underperform compared to an April Fools meme, threatening motivation and shaping what content he ‘should’ make.
key_stories.process: He compares view counts across multiple uploads, theorizes that YouTube has entered a “background noise” era, and brainstorms clickbaitier/ChatGPT-generated video ideas while acknowledging his core audience split (programmers vs casual viewers).
key_stories.outcome: He considers making a similar April 1st video annually as a tradition, while still wanting to pursue deep technical topics—even if they draw fewer views.
key_stories.key_quote: Even though that video was an April Fool’s joke, it did better than most of my normal videos.

key_stories.title: Proving the engine: real-N64 footage with extreme draw distance and big FPS gains
key_stories.summary: Kaze uses real-hardware footage to show how far the project’s engine optimizations have pushed Mario 64 visually—especially draw distance and scene complexity. It’s a credibility moment: he’s not just promising improvements; he’s demonstrating them on original hardware.
key_stories.challenge: Make large, detail-heavy RTYI environments run acceptably (and look modern) under N64 constraints; also address artifacts when FPS dips below 30 due to interpolation behavior.
key_stories.process: He references earlier performance baselines (e.g., the zoo area at ~9 FPS on the original engine), describes subsequent rewrites and major optimizations, then demonstrates Course 1 with near-infinite draw distance on N64 while observing interpolation glitches around ~20 FPS.
key_stories.outcome: The project is positioned as visually comparable to later-generation consoles in some scenarios, with remaining technical debt around stability/crashes and low-FPS interpolation edge cases.
key_stories.key_quote: Look at this. This is an N64 game.

open_questions.context: Kaze wants a very hard final level/boss, but worries that if one level is much harder than the rest, 100% players will get disproportionately frustrated. He suggests a buffer of ~44–45 Yoshi stars so casual players can finish without full completion, while completionists face the hardest content.
questions: What’s your ideal ‘contract’ with the player for RTYI—should beating the story be accessible while 100% is brutally hard, or should difficulty stay consistent throughout?
Do you envision the final level being gated by a specific completion threshold (e.g., all Yoshi stars), and how did you land on that threshold?
Can you recall other games that shaped your thinking here (positive or negative examples), and what you want RTYI to avoid?

open_questions.topic: Where to draw the line on player options (accessibility vs scope creep)
open_questions.context: Kaze is annoyed by requests for cosmetic toggles (old HUD/meters/fonts) and prefers fewer, more meaningful options. He’s open to some accessibility-like options (e.g., tutorials off), but doesn’t want every detail configurable.
questions: What criteria do you use to decide ‘this should be an option’ versus ‘this is the definitive RTYI experience’?
Have viewer requests for options ever changed your mind in a meaningful way—either adding something you later liked or refusing something that later caused backlash?
How do you want players to talk about RTYI—one shared experience, or many personalized variants?

open_questions.topic: Stability and performance roadmap (especially real-N64 edge cases)
open_questions.context: Kaze says the game currently runs fast but isn’t stable (crashes). He also observes interpolation artifacts when FPS drops below 30 and highlights past bugs that only happened on real N64 (DMA alignment).
questions: What are the main root causes behind the current instability/crashing—content issues, engine issues, memory fragmentation, or something else?
How do you test and prioritize emulator vs real-hardware bugs, given the time cost of diagnosing N64-only issues like DMA alignment?
What’s your plan for handling sub-30 FPS interpolation artifacts—fix the algorithm, clamp behaviors, or design levels to avoid dips?
